senses.de: to live or work in a place
senses.ex: People have occupied these houses for hundreds of years.

Tips.title: Place Association
Tips.description: Use 'occupy' to express the connection someone has with a place.
Tips.example: She has occupied that office since the company's founding.

Tips.title: Duration Implication
Tips.description: Implies long-term presence, not just a temporary stay.
Tips.example: The family occupied the farmhouse through generations.

senses.de: to fill or use a space, area, or amount of time
senses.ex: The meeting occupied the entire morning.

Tips.title: Exclusive Use
Tips.description: Indicates something exclusively fills up a space or time.
Tips.example: The new piano occupied most of the living room.

Tips.title: Preclusive Nature
Tips.description: Highlights that when occupied, space is not available for others.
Tips.example: The files occupied the entire shelf, leaving no room for anything else.

senses.de: to take control of a place by force

Tips.title: Power Dynamics
Tips.description: Conveys domination or control over a location.
Tips.example: The strategy was to occupy key positions around the enemy camp.

Tips.title: Temporal Aspect
Tips.description: Often refers to a historical event or military action.
Tips.example: The region was occupied during the war for several years.

senses.ex: The children were occupied with their toys.

Tips.title: Activity Involvement
Tips.description: Associated with keeping minds or bodies actively engaged.
Tips.example: He occupied his time by learning to play the guitar.

Tips.title: Distraction Potential
Tips.description: Suggests being absorbed in an activity to avoid boredom or stress.
Tips.example: She was occupied reading novels all weekend.

Absorb.wordDefinition:
Absorb means to take in or soak up something completely. It is applicable when something is soaked in a liquid and takes it in fully, or when someone is mentally taking in information or an experience.

Absorb means to take in fully, while occupy means to fill up space or attention.

Dwell.wordDefinition:
Dwell means to live in a particular place.

It can be used when referring to a permanent or long-term residence. For example, "I dwell in a small house in the countryside.".

In short, while dwell refers to a place where one lives, occupy denotes taking possession or control of a specific space or place.

Employ.wordDefinition: Employ means to hire or engage someone to do work for you. It is applicable when an employer hires an employee for work.

Engross.wordDefinition:
Engross means to absorb all of someone's attention or interest. For example, "The book was so engrossing that I could not put it down." Or "The speaker was so engrossed in her presentation that she didn't even notice the time passing.".

Occupy is used more in the sense of taking up a physical or temporal space or attention, while engross is used more in the sense of taking up someone's mental attention or interest.

Fill.wordDefinition: Fill means to make an empty space full of something. It is applicable when there is a space that needs to be filled with a substance, such as a glass needs to be filled with water or a bag needs to be filled with groceries.

Inhabit.wordDefinition:
Inhabit means to live in a place, while the word occupy means to possess or reside in a place.

For example, birds typically inhabit trees, meaning they live in them. A person can occupy a home or building, meaning they possess or reside in it.

Inhabit describes living organisms living in a particular place, while occupy describes possession or residence in a place.

Live in.wordDefinition:
Live in refers to residing or staying in a particular place as one's home, while occupy refers to the act of being present in or using a place or space for some purpose, such as for work or temporary shelter.

For example, one 'lives in' their own house or apartment, while a company might occupy a building for their offices. Live in usually refers to a more permanent arrangement, while occupy can refer to a temporary or more transient situation.

Reside.wordDefinition:
Occupy means to use, fill, or inhabit a space or place, without necessarily implying a permanent residence or ownership.

Reside means to live permanently or for an extended period of time in a particular place or dwelling. For example, a person might reside in an apartment or a house, and it implies a degree of ownership or long-term use of the space.

Occupy implies temporary or fleeting use, while reside implies more permanent ownership or residence.

quotes.Text: Sometimes you write music to a script or while a film is being edited. Sometimes I write without seeing any images, but that's rare. The approach is often based on practical decisions, but I'm interested in the narrative and physical space that music can occupy in a film or play.
quotes.Title: Icelander Composer
quotes.Name: Johann Johannsson

quotes.Text: With 'J', at a deep base level, there is still some comedy, but that masculinist voice that had driven so many of my novels I suddenly did not want to occupy. I wasn't reneging on it; I just didn't want to do it.
quotes.Title: British Novelist
quotes.Name: Howard Jacobson

quotes.Text: Your life is yours to live, no matter how you choose to live it. When you do not think about how you intend to live it, it lives you. When you occupy it, step into it consciously, you live it.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Gary Zukav

quotes.Text: Occupying armies have responsibilities, not rights. Their primary responsibility is to withdraw as quickly and expeditiously as possible, in a manner determined by the occupied population.
quotes.Title: American Activist
quotes.Name: Noam Chomsky

quotes.Text: When we are afraid we ought not to occupy ourselves with endeavoring to prove that there is no danger, but in strengthening ourselves to go on in spite of the danger.
quotes.Title: British Writer
quotes.Name: Hale White

quotes.Text: I don't know the literary world; I was scared of being confronted with famous names, not knowing what they had written. It was occupied territory I was entering.
quotes.Title: English Writer
quotes.Name: John le Carre

quotes.Text: The habits of study in which I have been brought up have done much to support me. I never allow myself to be one moment unoccupied.
quotes.Title: Scottish Writer
quotes.Name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

quotes.Text: No man who is occupied in doing a very difficult thing, and doing it very well, ever loses his self-respect.
quotes.Title: Irish Playwright
quotes.Name: George Bernard Shaw

quotes.Text: There must not be favoured treatment for those occupying a position of public responsibility.
quotes.Title: Spanish Royalty
quotes.Name: Felipe VI of Spain

quotes.Text: Moral science is better occupied when treating of friendship than of justice.
quotes.Title: Italian Theologian
quotes.Name: Thomas Aquinas
